reviewText:
I have been a fan of the Picross puzzle games for almost a decade now, having completed all the Nintendo-produced titles on the DS and 3DS and even going back and playing Mario's Picross through the 3DS's Virtual Console. I love the simplicity of the format and how they can, at times, seem impossible to complete until you find that one tiny, little detail you missed and the rest of the picture comes into play.

Paint it Back is missing a couple of the smaller details that makes those Nintendo games special but it includes a ton of puzzles, has much bigger puzzles than any of the Nintendo titles, and presents all of them with a great amount of polish, from snappy menus to configurable control schemes to solid performance. This is a really freaking good Picross game on the PC. If you like Picross games then that should really be enough to convince you. If you want more detail, I have lists.

Pros:
The game runs well on Windows 7, 8 and 10, with no noticeable load times or crashes (so far).
It works with multiple controllers right out of the gate, including the Xbox One pad, which is how I played most of the time.
You can switch between a mouse/keyboard combo and a controller at will, even mid-puzzle, and it only takes the game a second to figure out what you're using.
It's very challenging in spots, even more so than the hardest puzzles in Picross DS. Some of the sets are massive, going past 30x30 in size. This is where it's great to have a big screen. My PC is connected to my 40 TV and it was so nice to play wider puzzles that took up the length of my screen
date: all while lying on my couch.\nThe bigger puzzles can be broken down into bite-sized pieces
recommended: making them easier to digest. Instead of doing a 20x20 puzzle
voteText: you can do four 5x5 ones. You get a different amount of ribbons (the game's way to measure progress) based on whether you tackle the whole thing at once or in parts.\nThere's enough content to last over 20 hours
votesHelpful: and a good variety of difficulties from easy to moderately challenging to bang-your-head-against-the-wall hard puzzles
votesTotal: all of which you can save and come back to later if you get too burnt out.\nColumns and rows highlight to help you navigate
votesFunny: which doesn't really matter until you get to the latter puzzles
column16: but when you do it's super helpful.\nIt's a small download and doesn't require a ton of resources so you can play on a laptop without much of a challenge. I found it just as fun to use the arrows and the z/x button combo as the controller.\nit's Picross on your PC. That
column18: is an amazing thing. Even if the game wasn't built well I'd still be happy. Fortunately enough
column19: it is really polished.\nCons:\nThere's no mode or option that you can toggle that'll mark when you make a mistake (at least that I could find). Meaning that if you screw up with a fill instead of an X or vice versa
column20: you won't know it until later when things don't add up. Most of the time I didn't mind this
column21: since you're filling in tons of squares and a simple slip of the thumb might happen
column24: would have been welcome.\nFor better or worse
column25: not all the achievements have detailed explanations.\nI would have liked more of the wide puzzles and less of the tall ones
column28: and it fits better.\nThe music gets incredibly repetitive after a couple hours."

reviewText:
Puzzle Lovers delight!

In the past I've only tried this type of puzzle on paper in puzzle books, but did not get very far with them because of having to erase mistakes, but there would still be some shading left from where I erased and it got confusing.  But with this game I can paint and erase with the flick of a mouse.  Much easier.

For those who have never encountered this type of puzzle before I'm gonna quote from wikipedia:

Nonograms
hoursPlayed: are picture logic puzzles in which cells in a grid must be colored or left blank according to numbers at the side of the grid to reveal a hidden picture."\n\nIt's kind of like a binary sudoku.  If you love logic puzzles
voteText:
you will like this.  I quickly got addicted.

How does it work:
You've got a grid of squares and you are told how many spaces are supposed to be colored in on each row and column.  Use logic to choose what to color in.  When you are finished it forms a picture.  You only use black and white
helpfulPercent: but there is a colored painting that appears as you work on the puzzle.  You don't actually have to choose colors yourself
votesHelpful:
it does it automatically.

Difficulty Settings:
There are 3 difficulty levels.  The beginning puzzles are only on the easiest difficulty
votesTotal: but as you progress in later galleries you can choose which difficulty level you want for each painting.  And even after you finish a puzzle you can redo it on another difficulty level.\n\nThe puzzles also come in different sizes.  From 10x10 to 30x30 and other odd sizes.  The easy difficulty splits the large puzzles into sections
votesFunny:
so you might have to do 4 sections to complete 1 whole puzzle picture.  The hardest difficulty is just one giant grid.

How many puzzles:
Puzzle paintings are organized into Galleries with themes
column19: etc.  If forget exactly how many puzzles are in each gallery
column20:
maybe about 8-10 or so.  You unlock more galleries as you complete puzzles are get the medals.  You get more medals for solving on higher difficulty.

Help Tools:
If you need help there are some in-game help tools that you can activate
column21:
though you might not get a medal for solving that puzzle.

Story:
Yes
column22:
a puzzle game with a story!  There is a cute little story scene in the beginning.  And a small one once you complete all the puzzles once on any difficulty.

Graphics:
Cute and colorful.

Sound:
Nice effects like paint splat sounds when you mark a puzzle.  The background music has several tracks that loop continously.

Interface:
I used a mouse.  No problems.

Replay value:
Once you get pretty far into the puzzles you unlock Mystery mode.  Where you can try to solve a random puzzle (from one of the galleries) only it does not show you the progress in the little picture and doesn't tell you the title
column23: either.  So you have to do it by logic only
column24:
no guessing!  You can choose any difficulty level in Mystery mode.

Achievements!
All of the achievements are easily doable
column25:
just takes some time.  There aren't any super hard achievements (so far).

A Painter is Never Satisfied with his finished product.
The developer listens to the fans and has made updates with new features based on ideas from fans.  It's always nice to see a dev willing to tweek his game if the fans want something.

I can't remember how much it cost but it's well worth it.  And I actually bought my copy
column26: unlike some people who got free review copies.\n\nThat's all I can think of to say.  Just about the perfect puzzle game.  A little story
column28: lots of options for difficulty.  Oh and there is humor as well.  Some of the painting titles are puns on famous paintings or pop culture references.  If you like logic puzzles
column29: you can't go wrong with this game.\n"

reviewText:
A refreshing take on Nonograms/Picross. The core gameplay is nothing new, but the presentation is just superb.

It has a lot of pictures to solve (all of them original) and some additional challenges, for example limiting your use of crosses.

The few flaws that the game had were addressed by the very responsive developer.

★★★★★★★★★☆

reviewText:
This is a good nonogram puzzle game.

It has 150+ black and white nonograms, but the picture they encode are in color (upper left on the screenshots), so the shapes are not always obvious. Sizes range from 5x5 to 40x30. For the larger sizes, there are options to break them up into smaller parts to make them easier to solve, but you get less rewards. There are also rewards for not using X marks, for not making mistakes, and for being fast. Because there's a challenge mode where it will select a random puzzle of the whole set for you to do without telling you which one it is, there is limited replayability. The interface is ok.

If you like these types of puzzles, you can confidently buy this game. (There's a demo, too.)
voteText: 14 of 15 people (93%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
While it's hard to go wrong with a casual picross/nonogram game, this game makes a lot of decisions that I like. Puzzles are non-linear, the difficulty varies from very easy to very hard based on user choice, and there's no time restriction. While the storyline is tenuous, let's be honest, you're not buying this game for the story.

Simple game structure, but a large variety of puzzles for any skill level.

Would definitely recommend.

reviewText:
A very nice addition to the puzzle genre with a sweet and fun cartoonish look.
The pixel art in the game get's better and better with every level.
Developer: Casual Labs
Publisher: Casual Labs
Release Date: October 14th, 2015

Paint it Back is on the trail of Sudoku which I guess everyone of us has played at least once so far. It’s a really good and fun game that you can pick up whenever you feel like it.
It started out on iOS and is now here on Steam.

StoryA ghost appeared and literally spooked the paintings away.
So it’s now your job to … Paint it back.

Seriously that’s pretty much it and there’s no need for a fancy storyline.

GameplayIf you’ve played Sudoku then the game’s pretty much self explanatory and in case you haven’t well the tutorial does one fine job explaining it.
Let’s get into it. You start of by facing a blank 5x5 field and you have to paint the right squares while leaving others blank. Later on in the game you’ll have to repaint bigger like 16x20.
The game even tells you not to guess but to think. Sure you could guess your way through the early levels and the smaller painting but good luck with that for the bigger ones.

Your only tool is a brush with black paint. You don’t have to worry about choosing the right color for the right square. All you have to do is to paint the right ones. The other tool you have is the right click. If you right click a square you’ll cross it out so you know that you have it blank.
The game, just like sudoku, gives you some hints so you know where to start and which squares to paint.
On the outside of the field of your painting you see certain numbers. Let’s say the upper left row starts, vertically, with a 4. That means that you have to paint 4 squares in this row and so on.
Some fields have more than one number on the outside. The first number or in this case the outer number’s the same as before and tells you how many squares you have to paint. The second number however tells you that you have to leave some squares blank and then start painting again. Let me demonstrate on a 5x5 field.
Let’s say the upper left, vertically, row starts with a 2 and the next number is a 2 as well.
That would mean that you have to paint two squares, leave one open, and then paint again two.
So you see you get the hang of it pretty quickly.

The game does require a fair amount of brain power though. The beauty of it is that, just as the developers name implies, it’s really a casual game that you can pick up whenever you want.
You can even save your progress in your current painting and come back later to it to finish it.

VisualsThe game itself has a cartoonish look to it and is quite fitting. The paintings however look great.
The pixel art in the game’s pretty fun, good looking and for me easily the best part of the game.
The early painting might not look the best but they’ll look better and better in the higher levels and way more complex.
Overall it’s a fairly nice and sweet looking game and the whole cartoonish art style was a good choice.

AudioThe music just fits and manages to stay in the background while also maintaining presence.
It’s not too subtle but at the same time not too intrusive.
I mean at the end of the day you’ll find yourself paying attention to the music and it will probably hinder you a bit but it’s not too bad.
The tracks used however are quite short which I personally actually like since the level that you’re stuck on won’t get too dull too fast.

What else can I say?I have been lucky enough to get a Review Key for Paint it Back in order to write a blunt and honest to God Review. Just as usual.

It is what it is. It’s a nice game for every now and then when you feel like you need something for your brain. Overall it works pretty good and I haven’t had any problems whatsoever.
It’s hard though. Well hard as in some levels are truly complex and require a fair amount of time and you can’t just rush through all of the levels. At the end of the day you’ll probably get a fair amount of gametime out of it if you don’t get too frustrated later on.

The perfect game for every puzzle lover. Especially for people that just need their fix every now and then.

No drama, Just Reviews.

- Neku

reviewText:
https://youtu.be/0reZ7geGKMo
Game: Paint it Back
Genre: Nonogram Puzzle
Developer: Casual Labs
Publisher: Casual Labs
Copy supplied by developer

Paint it Back is a picross/nonogram puzzle game developed and published by Casual Labs.

STORYThe story is basically non-existent: you are the curator of an art gallery, and, after a ghost has stolen the content of every painting, it is your job to paint them back (get it?) and re-open the exhibition. Since there are no cutscenes other than the initial one, I'm not gonna take this into account.

GRAPHICSThe game adopts a very colorful art-style that well suits both the tone of the different rooms full of paintings and the puzzles that you complete. While the paintings get bigger and more complex the more you paint them, most of them are still very simple and lack detail.

GAMEPLAYThe game is essentially a digital version of nonogram:  are picture logic puzzles in which cells in a grid must be colored or left blank according to numbers at the side of the grid to reveal a hidden picture. In this puzzle type, the numbers are a form of discrete tomography that measures how many unbroken lines of filled-in squares there are in any given row or column.
I had never played this type of puzzle, and it has easily become my favourite: the constant calculation of numbers and the huge satisfaction of seeing a finished work make this game one of the most relaxing and easier to get games of the year.

CHALLENGEThe game's puzzles get increasingly difficult, but you can always choose the difficulty of each one (for example, for a 50x50 puzzle you can choose Normal to complete small 10x10 areas). They are never impossible to complete, and usually waiting a couple of minutes to clear your head up helps.

SOUNDThe soundtrack to the game is quirky and relaxing, making this game one to be picked up when you want to chill for 5 or 10 minutes.

REPLAYABILITYThe game features a total of 150 paintings to complete and 20 Steam achievements to unlock, giving you more thane enough content for its cheap price.

Overall, both fans and non-fans of puzzle games (especially nonogram/picross) will enjoy this game thanks to its simplicity, challenge, huge satisfaction and relaxing soundtrack.

reviewText:
IntroductionPicross. That’s the thing I keep hearing whenever I see games like this come by. These sorts of games are easily spotted, because of the large squares with numbers on the sides, and a picture of what you’re creating in the corner. I remember having played one or two of them back in the day but to be honest I can’t remember what they were like. Time to find out if there may have been a reason for this…

GameplayThe story is quite simple and begins with a ghost wandering around in a museum. It finally manages to scare away all of the paintings and now it’s up to you to paint them back. It’s goofy and it sets the tone immediately. It doesn’t take itself seriously and that’s exactly what it should be like. It’s a casual game at heart, as in anyone can pick it up and play. The difficulty is also targeted at a casual audience and since there’s no time limit you can take your time until you have finally figured out how to paint it properly. However, you can also choose to play a more difficult/advanced version of puzzles and these puzzles then consist of multiple blocks merged together to make it look like one big (wide) puzzle.

Gameplay wise it’s relatively simple. Easy to learn, even easy to master, but it does take some brain activity to figure out how to paint the blocks exactly. The game puts a board in front of you and that board can also be seen in the upper left corner, but on a smaller scale. If you paint a block on the big board – by just clicking on it – then you will also see that block get painted on the smaller board in the corner. By clicking a block again you can remove the paint and by right-clicking you can choose to disable a block to prevent you from accidentally painting over it. While I felt this was fairly useless at the beginning it became more important later on when the boards get bigger and more complex.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=536135165
Anyway, there are numbers written on the top and left sides of the board and these tell you how to paint the blocks. By looking at the numbers you can figure out how to paint the blocks properly.
So if you have a 10x10 block and on the ninth line (horizontally) is written ‘10’ then you have paint all ten blocks horizontally. It’s not a very good example, but it’s a little hard to explain without actually drawing an example. But just take a look at the screenshots and you’ll see probably understand what I mean.

Once the painting is complete the smaller board will be enlarged to show you the end result. It’s always a pixel art painting (I always appreciate good pixel art) so don’t go and expect a DaVinci painting or anything, although they do get more complex a few hours into the game.
Also, starting from area 3 puzzles become larger and may even consist of several parts. This means that a painting can be divided into, for example, 2, 4 or 6 parts. This doesn’t influence the actual coloring of the blocks but instead of creating just one big painting you’re then painting several parts that ultimately combine into one big painting. You do get to see the entire painting in the corner, by the way, so you always have a clear idea of what the final result will or should look like.

There are multiple areas to play through, 15 in fact, each with their own theme, but I somehow missed how these paintings exactly relate to these worlds. They seem completely random, but I guess with a little thinking you can see the or some sort of relation between them. It seems farfetched, though, but I assume that’s just part of the goofy style and humor.

Overall the game feels very polished. The only thing I think needs improvement is the audio, of which there is just too little variety. With some added tracks (or at least more rotation) it’s actually pretty much perfect in my opinion.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=536135007
Audio & VisualsSo, thus far there doesn’t seem to be a whole lot of diversity as far the music is concerned. The first hour or so I heard the same song over and over with every painting I created. Then out of nowhere I finally heard another song. There seem to be more songs but they currently repeat a bit too often, which is an absolute shame, even though the focus is not the music per se. But more variety (as in: more tracks, or more rotation) would definitely help add to the immersion of being (or at least feeling like) a painter.

Visually it’s a beautiful game with a great looking cartoony style. The cinematics (although I wouldn’t really call them that) look fabulous in motion and the boards animate nicely whenever you complete a painting. Other than that there’s not much animation. The pixel art shown in the frames looks great, but sometimes it still looks a bit too simple. I personally thought it would’ve been cool if the pixel art would animate upon completing a puzzle. It would give it just a little more personality, but to be totally honest you can’t say that this game lacks any. It bursts with personality actually.
Anyway, the text is sharp, the use of colors is diverse and the graphics scale nicely: the game makes the screen (not the game itself) less wide or wider based on what is shown. It looks cool, but is a little inconsistent.
(Please note that I’m playing on a 21:9 monitor and this may therefore not occur on your monitor.)

Length/Replay ValueThere are 150 paintings to complete in total. Most of them can be completed in just a couple of minutes so if you do the math then it should take you anywhere between 10-15 hours to complete. And this is just for the normal paintings. If you choose to complete more advanced paintings then you can easily add another dozen hours to that number. Plus, there’s an Endless Mode for even MORE replay value. Oh yes, you get plenty of bang for your buck. Guaranteed!

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=536135313
ConclusionOkay, so I might not remember the Picross games (maybe due to a lack of interest, or maybe I didn’t have the right age, who knows?) but I will try to remember Paint It Back this time. It has become a game that anyone can play and have fun with: a relaxing game meant to be played for just a few minutes or a couple of hours. I definitely had fun with it.
There aren’t many games like this available on PC (or more specifically: Steam) and so it might not become insanely popular (yet). But let’s make sure it at least gets the attention it deserves. Buy it and recommend it if you agree!

Too long, didn’t readPros:
+ Artistic graphics complement the style of the game
+ Fun, at times challenging, puzzles
+ Anyone can play it; it’s very easy to pick up and learn
+ Extremely relaxing atmosphere

Mixed:

Cons:
- Music tracks repeat too often, or there aren’t enough tracks

reviewText: Absolutely LOVE the game. The puzzles are nonogram puzzles and although they start out small, they get to the point where they are quite a challenge. However, if you like easier puzzles, there is the option to complete the larger puzzles in small pieces, allowing all puzzles to be completed at the difficultly level you feel like attempting at the time. The controls feel smooth whether using the mouse, the keyboard, or a controller, and switching between these options at any time is automatic and seemless. The paintings can be quite entertaining, and several have left me in suspense as to what the subject is right up until the end. There are a vast number of paintings, and the mystery masterpiece mode allows for the feeling of fresh new puzzles even once you've completed them all. There is a massive amount of place time availible here, making the game well worth the price. On top of all this, the dev is extrodinarily nice and responsive. I highly recomend this game to anyone interested in puzzle games.

reviewText:
A very nice Picross game with a tonne of puzzles. Interface is nice, and it doesn't make you spend hours doing really easy ones.

My only gripes would be that the difficulty sometimes seems a bit random and there are some puzzles that as far as I can tell can't logically be deduced. There've been quite a few where I just had to give up after doing half the puzzle because the other half was very ambiguous.

The other issue is kind of opposite to that: some squares are lighter and darker based on the picture being drawn. This, and being able to see the picture being drawn in the top left, lead to situations where it's extremely easy to guess where the squares are meant to go, which kind of ruins the challenge of Picross. I would much prefer if all the squares were straight black and I couldn't see the painting in the top.

In any case, it's well worth the money. Just a few things that kind of ruin the spirit of the game.

hoursPlayed: something I personally really don't like to do when puzzling).\nStill
voteText:
besides that one I think the difficulty and logic for this game fit perfectly.

The only thing I really disliked was the fact that the numbers on the side / at the top already turned grey the second the correct number of black spots was there on the field (as long as it had a direkt connection with blacks and Xs to one of the sides). I usually play Nintendo's Picross games and there they only grey out the numbers when the black spots have an X (or the end of the picture) on both sides.
So I would really have preferred an option to either manage it like that or to maybe grey the numbers out manually. That would mean more work for me but as I prefer having 'perfect' scores (as in
helpfulPercent: no wrongly set black spots ever if possible) this turned out to be really annoying during the mystery masterpiece runs.\n\nBut that's a really minor complain for I still had a lot of fun with this game and I will certainly play it again

reviewText:
Paint It Back is a great nonogram puzzle game with a painting theme that I am absolutely addicted to (as you can probably tell from my playtime). A nonogram is a puzzle where you are given a grid and each row and column has one or more numbers by it which tells you how many consecutive cells need to be filled in in that row or column. You will need to use logical thinking and information from other rows and columns to figure out which cells are the ones that should be filled in and complete the painting.

It's hard to explain why Paint It Back is so addicting but it is. It is definitely one of those one more turn" type of games. You will sit down to play it for an hour to wind down and it will be past midnight before you know it. I think the main reason why it is so fun and addicting is that it is a very simple game to play but it also requires a lot of logical thinking to complete the paintings.

Paint It Back offers a lot of bang for your buck. At the time of this review
date:
I had put in over 21 hours and I still have a lot of puzzles left to complete. I estimate that it will take me at least 25 total hours to complete all of the puzzles and that's with me focusing on mainly the normal and pro paintings (the master difficulty puzzles are very time consuming).

If you like puzzle games at all and especially if you like nonograms or similar puzzles like Sudoku you should definitely check out Paint It Back.

Note: I received a free review copy of the game but received no other compensation for this review.

Read my full review [www.geekyhobbies.com]"

reviewText:
Remember Picross?
Well, here we are!

I've played countless hours of Picross 3D on my 3DS and Picross on NDS.
The thing is: This games gives the same feeling - in a different way.

It's like Picross twisted with some random and crazy drawings. It's full of crazy pictures. A game so simple, and yet challenging. When I downloaded the demo, and finished it, I've started counting the hours so I could get the full game.

It's a nice work. Simple to get, and yet, challenging to master.
If you're looking for a great way to pass time, this game might be a good choice.

Paint it Back is a fun and sometimes challenging Picross style puzzle game where you must restore paintings using logical thinking. It is a great game to play while relaxing and listening to music. I've spent many hours working on completing all the puzzles on all the difficulties, you definately get your money's worth from it. It is a must by if you love puzzle games.

A wonderful addition to the Picross family of games. If you like Sudoku and want a relaxing yet rewarding direction to move in, you have found your game here!

Even though I just bought two new Picross games, I keep coming back to this one again and again for its wacky (and often surprisingly dark!) sense of humor, its reverent irreverence for classical art (yes, I did mean that), and its colorful, inviting interface. Puzzles are often quite challenging on Pro or Master mode, and unlike Picross it does not punish you for making a stray mistaken mark, although neither does it inform you of your errors, so guessers beware! Only good, logical thought can solve these puzzles.

Cons? Well, the music, while catchy at first, quickly becomes tiresome, and some of the achievements have odd requirements, but I'm really nit-picking here. This is a darned fine game, and I feel confident recommending it to anyone and everyone. Happy 'painting'!
Very good Picross game with a large number of puzzles, definitely worth trying if you like Picross.\n\nCan be played with a mouse, keyboard or gamepad.

This is a solid picross game that doesn\'t stray much from the standard formula, but it doesn\'t need to.\n\nThere\'s a large number of puzzles available, probably at least 30 hours\' worth of \official\" ones in the game without even getting into the ones available from the Steam Workshop. The picture themes are amusing and bizarre
date: and some of the harder ones are quite large
recommended: with dimensions like 40x30. For people that don\'t want something quite that difficult
hoursPlayed: you also have the option of splitting the larger puzzles into \"sections\" so that you work on multiple smaller puzzles that all combine into the overall image in the end.\n\nIt plays well using any one of a mouse
votesHelpful: and the controls are customizable if needed. The interface has a few other nice aspects as well
votesTotal: including a \"mark mode\" where you can test some guesses out in a different color (necessary for a couple of the hardest puzzles).\n\nDefinitely recommended if you enjoy logic puzzles (and picross games in particular). Excellent value

reviewText:
- A Good Kick For Casual Gamers -

The game offers a lot of content and presents itself really well, so if you are interested in trying a pic-cross game you´ll find what you need here.
The pictures are all interesting and seeing what you actually drew in the end, how it perfectly fits with the theme, is always a sight to behold. The later levels can get quite difficult, tho as they all have multiple difficulties, newcomers will have no problem to enjoy the game until the end.

If you already know that you like this sort of game however, i´d have to recommend to not buy this. There are many pic-cross games out there, many even free, and the problem this one in particular has, is that you will have to guess in some later stages. Until then many hours will pass, but if you want to play and enjoy every single level, you won´t be able to.

reviewText: I don't know how I got it, but Mario's Picross was my favorite Game Boy game as a kid. Later Picross DS was one of my favorite DS games. And then I never found another good one until Paint It Back on iOS. The pictures are fun, there are a lot of puzzles, and the varied difficulty levels mean anybody can enjoy. All of that comes through in the Steam version, and the mouse controls are great (left click for paint, right click for x).\n\nPaint it Back is, for me, right up there with the Hexcells games. Fantastic puzzles, simple controls, and if you're doing it right you never ever have to guess.

reviewText:
It's Picross (or whatever you prefer to call it). It's on Steam. The interface is serviceable, music is decent, controls are as simple as left and right click, the puzzles go all the way up to 40x30 (40x40 for usermade), AND there's integrated Steam Workshop support for custom puzzles.

This is it. This is the one. The nonogram game PCs have deserved all this time. And it's a dang mobile port no less.

(Not to say it'd be impossible to make the interface a little more interesting, but hey, nitpicks.)

reviewText: It's Picross, presented in a clean, easy-to-work-with interface. Left click fills a box, right click marks it as empty. You can also switch left click back-and-forth between the two, which you might inadvertently do if you use the Steam overlay. The early puzzles may be easy, but the game gets tough quickly - there's easily your money's worth here in sheer hours-per-dollar, even more if you're as bad at Picross as me. As an added bonus, some of the jokes are funny.

Good, simple fun. Great presentation, with an art style that reminds me of the Spy Fox games, and a suprisingly good sense of humour. Check out the demo and if you like it, I'd say it's definitely worth the money as there is a lot of content for the price.

This is like Mario's Picross.

If you like Hexcells, get this game! Very similar kind of logic used. Excellent casual puzzler. Challenging enough that you have to think about what you're doing, but not so hard you want to pull your hair out. Some of the pictures of quite cute, too.

At first it seems painfully easy but then you get to the painting with multiple difficulties. It's logic is similar to Sudoku and it plays a lot like Hexcells (also on steam).  The story and asthetics are cute and make it feel family friendly, so I would recommend it to children; perhaps above the age of...hmmm...10? But you need not worry about the challenge as it is choosable most of the time. I've had great fun and great frustration playing this, definitly recommend!

This game, however, does satisfy, with tons of puzzles and good meaty challenge. Also, the picture for the Exhibitionist" achievement is a guy flashing you with a painting."

Great picross-style puzzle game with tons and tons of puzzles to keep ya plenty busy. Once you're done with all the puzzles, which at 33 hours I'm still not quite, there's still a bit of replayability to earn medals in a 'mystery' style mode.

Very good puzzle/logic game.

I love these kinds of puzzle games for playing whilst I'm doing other things, and this game has certainly provided a good few hours of puzzle-solving distraction. It's pretty much what it looks like - a logic puzzle game where you 'create' pixel art based on number clues given to you.

Pros
+ Quirky bright graphics
+ Easy to use interface
+ Decent number of puzzles
+ Sufficient level of challenge and the player chooses which challenge level they'd like for each puzzle
+ Few additional things to aim for over and above just finishing the puzzles, if you want to earn all the achievements

Cons
- I might be wrong, but I don't think all of the 'master' level puzzles are solvable through logic alone. If true, that's not great - I don't want to be forced to play out a guess in these kinds of puzzles.
*Edit - Although I still don't agree with having puzzles in the game that are unsolvable by traditional methods, I do want to add that the developer is extremely responsive and as a result of mine and others' feedback has added a message in the game that lets you know if a puzzle requires the mark-up mode before you start it. I'm impressed by their response to constructive criticism as too often (in my opinion) devs either don't respond or respond badly it seems. Kudos to the devs on this one.

Would have been nice to have
Not exactly 'cons', but... While you're solving each puzzle there's a 'painting' in the top left which paints the pixels in colours as you progress. In some cases, this made it obvious where the next squares should go - I hid the painting by using windowed mode and pushing it off the screen, but it would be nice to switch this off. (I didn't spot this option in the settings). Also, and this is really a personal preference, but my favourite logic puzzles are ones with text puzzles to help you solve the grid, so it would have been great to see a few of these thrown in to mix it up a little.

All in all, does what it says on the tin, and if you like grid-based logic puzzles, you'll like this game.
One of the best Picross game I've ever played! Awesome to see this type of game on Steam. Gamepad controls great. I would pay for coming DLCs without thinking ;)

reviewText: In a nutshell, it is picross.  However, it has a certain charm that is difficult to ignore.  The music puts me in mind of Mario Paint (remember that?), and though it starts of insultingly easy, it gets harder the further you progress.\nThe higher difficulty sees you completing whole paintings in one go, whilst the lower difficulty options allow you to tackle sections of the picture.  The addition of a 'helping hand' that corrects any mistakes you make always keeps it accessible if, like me, you aren't particularly good at puzzle games.\nA nice, simple, fun game to play when you get tired of blowing up bad guys ^_^

TL;DR: Paint it Back is a pleasant and fairly challenging collection of nonograms with some nice and curious pixel art.

When I bought it I didn't expect Paint it Back to last over 40 hours but it did anyway. After all at its core it is just a (fairly large) collection of nonograms[en.wikipedia.org], also known as grittlers or hanjies.

In case you don't know them, in nonograms you are given a grid of boxes and a set of numbers at the edge. The numbers determine how many adjacent boxes are filled" in each row or column. In these puzzles the solution usually is designed to form a recognizable picture. All puzzles in the game have exactly one solution.

Smooth and casual gameplay
There is a flimsy (but working) back story to motivate using nonograms: a ghost has scared away all the paintings in a gallery. You are tasked to "paint" it all back.

The gallery has over dozen sections with separate themes each with circa ten puzzles of increasing difficulty per section. The puzzles are tiered in 3 difficulty settings pertaining to the size of the grid
date: from 5x5 (normal) to 40x30 (master).\n\nMouse controls work splendidly: left-click "paints"
recommended: right-click marks a box empty and both marks can be reversed by clicking again. There's also a test mark-up mode that one can use to try out and find conflicts when regular logic fails (essentially required in only a couple of the master-level paintings). A neat detail is that the color picture slowly forms in the corner while you are "painting".\n\nThe art is generally good and quirky and every painting is a small surprise
hoursPlayed:
so it's fun to solve the problems.

Perfect for what it is
When playing I like to alt+tab every now and then for small pauses. I was happy to note this didn't have any adverse effects on the game. Being a mobile port
voteText: there is the slightly redundant (considering Steam Family share) option to create up to 6 profiles for e.g. all family members. Despite this you can unfortunately have only one incomplete painting saved at the time (per profile I presume) although you can work on others
helpfulPercent: just without saving the progress if you wanted to quit.\n\nFor 100% achievement completion it took me almost 42 hours. I think that's a great amount of content for a game such as this. There's some repetition required for achievement hunters
votesHelpful: since about half of the medals (conveniently displayed also in-game) are about the random challenges that require you to complete a random existing painting in a specific way (including quickly
votesTotal: without empty-crosses and/or without "wasting paint"). Still
votesFunny: this adds only couple of hours to the whole gametime. The more difficult puzzles can be completed on lower difficulty levels as well (by solving them part-wise as several smaller nonograms) that might add even more content for completionists though it is not required for the achievements.\n\nHowever
commentsCount: it is just a collection of nonograms with no twists except perhaps for the quirky art. I got it for half the price and I was happy with the content but I might have been disappointed had I paid the full price. Unless you really love nonograms you should also wait for a sale."

reviewText: If you like the old Picross games, Paint It Back is right up your alley.

Definitely recommend this game to people who enjoy puzzle games (and/or art). The tutorial is LITERALLY amazing. It is hands down the best tutorial in a game ever. of all time. best tutorial ever. Now I came into this game already knowing how to play this type of puzzle game, so I rushed through the tutorial, but for a new player to this type of a puzzle game if they went through the tutorial all the information they need would be in that tutorial. Not only is it jam packed with several techniques and building blocks for other ones, it is very clear and precise. It also has a system to make sure you understand (which I'm very keen of).

After playing the tutorial I zoomed by the first gallery and I was sad that this game wouldn't be challenging because the puzzles were so easy (I'm an experienced player so the normal puzzles didnt teach me anything), but once I hit a Pro picture I was like dammmmmmm gurl nice. and then when I hit a Master picture I was like YES BOYS. And while the difficulty spike in my opinion shoots almost straight up, its very very fun. I have only played a few galleries, but I'm presuming the difficulty won't be going down, so I'm sure all of the galleries are really good! For the asking price and the content of this game, and the tutorial. I'd say this is a must buy steam game for puzzle genre lovers. I've even recommended it to friends because I feel like the tutorial is so good even noobs could start playing this game and end up a 'Master' level player.

The story line is brief, and the characters at the beginning of each gallery are commical for those who know art. I haven't gone past like the fourth or fifth gallery but I was a bit sad to see that you dont actually do the color part of the painting like instead of a row being 5 in a 5x5 board it could be 1121 and each number representing a different color. That would take away from the difficulty but I think it'd be really cool and I hope that I find it later on in the game. If it doesn't show up that's fine the game will still be amazing.  The UI (menu and the board itself) still needs some work to be 5/5, and I'm not the best judge for music, it's fairly good background music for this game(although one of the tracks, not sure which one, has a misleading sound in it aka a sound from another program that notifies sometime, although it's not that prominent).

Overall I'd give this game like a 4.8/5. I wanna give it the five but 5/5 is perfect and realistically the UI is not perfect so it'd be injust if I did so. Highly recommend this game!

Thanks to the developer(s) and everyone else involved for creating this! Definitely one of the best puzzle games I've played on steam. (:s the niche genre markets on steam are really weak.)

If you like Picross, it's your game. It's exactly what you get. A very good Picross version with an insane amount of content and an nice artstyle. The controls are perfect (which isn't that hard, I supoose, but a lot of developers seem to ♥♥♥♥ it up anyway).
Wish there was a Meh" option. If you liked Picross on the DS/3DS systems you'll probably enjoy this a bit

reviewText: In a nutshell, it is picross.  However, it has a certain charm that is difficult to ignore.  The music puts me in mind of Mario Paint (remember that?), and though it starts of insultingly easy, it gets harder the further you progress.\nThe higher difficulty sees you completing whole paintings in one go, whilst the lower difficulty options allow you to tackle sections of the picture.  The addition of a 'helping hand' that corrects any mistakes you make always keeps it accessible if, like me, you aren't particularly good at puzzle games.\nA nice, simple, fun game to play when you get tired of blowing up bad guys ^_^
If you like the old Picross games, Paint It Back is right up your alley.

Simplistic game, with straight forward mechanics. A Excellent video game version of Sudoku. Perfect for playing while watching movies and shows, and all around relaxing and great for winding down at the end of the day.
Very fun! As a computer programmer my next game is going to be a picross game. Never new this type of puzzle existed until now. Totally worth the buy.
If you want to play Picross on Steam - or on any decent-sized screen, for that matter - Paint It Back is an excellent substitute. You'll have no shortage of content to play.

Finally a game of this genre made it on steam.
At first it's putting you to sleep with only easy ones at 5x5 squares - but soon after there are really hard ones that can take some time to solve.
The music is getting quite annoying after a few minutes, but can be muted, so you can listen to anything you like.
Unfortunately there are only black&white griddlers - hopefully there will be a game that includes coloured ones as well soon.

Lovely little number based puzzle game I played for about 5 months on/off, finally finishing all the levels after 75 hours of time played. For a game that cost me 8€ this is quite a large amount of content. Obviously you need to enjoy the basic format of the game to keep coming back as it is very much repetitive. Fill in the correct blocks based on the information provided by the numbers for each column and row. The puzzles start out simple, teaching you the basic concepts, but also eventually giving you complicated puzzles that can take hours to solve.\n\nGreat game to play while watching something on your second screen!
A solid Picross game for your PC.

Ever wanted to play picross on your PC? Look no further, this game is just that.
You get numbers on both X & Y axis and need to fill in the corresponding blocks on the grid. Sounds easy enough? It gets harder depending on the grid size. Doesn't really sound that exciting, just like many other puzzle games until you start playing it and then... get hooked. Expect yourself to say - just one more - a lot of times. Puzzles can be saved and continued at a later time, certainly handy for the bigger ones as they can take some time to solve.
Ofcourse it helps if the implementation is well done, and there is no complaining about that here. The playful semi-cubic graphic style fits the game perfectly, as does the simple but effective soundtrack and sound effects. The game itself is funny and contains a lot of humor, pop culture references and sillyness.
Updates are still being made, just recently the capability was added to create your own puzzles and share them with other players. As such the replayability could be endless.
Works well on Linux/SteamOS and has smooth Steam Controller support, enabling both relaxed play through the Steam Link on the couch or directly on your PC. The game doesn't require a lot of resources, so I imagine it runs smooth on about any configuration you might have.
